comments.commentBody: “If you had seen one day of war, you would pray to God that you would never see another.” – Napoleon
Oh goody ..... now we can have another war

A stopped clock is right twice per day, and Democrats (including Obama) are not always right, but Republicans are never right. Period.

If they manage to scuttle this deal, the rest of the negotiators will simply move on, and lift the sanctions. As to the concern that Iran (which has not invaded another country in centuries but has been invaded and had its democratically elected government overthrown, through the US and US proxies) would start a nuclear war, that has as much credibility as the worry that the smoking gun could become a mushroom cloud.

"Many people don't want war but they want a stronger agreement."

Maybe they'd want to flap their arms to fly too.

There is no stronger agreement possible. The sanctions from the rest of the world will end, and ours don't mean much alone. This deal is it, or war.

But listen to McCain and read Bolton and all the other Republicans like them. They SAY they want war. Some just know that is so offensive to Americans that they fantasize about "a better deal."

Many people don't want war but they want a stronger agreement. This one has too many holes. Access to nuclear sites should be guaranteed. Instead Iran can demand that we "negotiate" access. They could delay and more importantly ask to see any evidence of a breach of the agreement which could expose intelligence assets.

If they develop a bomb others in the area will want one too. Suddenly very unstable governments will possess the means to start a nuclear war.

I marched against the Gulf War, but there are times when wars are necessary. Prevention of nuclear proliferation is one of those. The possibility of nuclear war is not a joke and we must do everything we can to reduce the chances of it. Keeping nuclear weapons away from unstable countries is one of those things.

Yes, Republicans have lost all credibility by opposing everything that Obama has tried to do. They politicized this whole process by bringing in Netanyahu, a man who lies whenever it is convenient. But despite all that, even a stopped clock is right twice per day.

By evil people I am assuming you mean the Iranians chanting "death to America"?
This isn't about race, it is about overreach. And 19-0 on the Foreign Relations Committee means it was supported by Dems and Republicans. Did you even read the article?

The most dangerous thing about the worst politicians is their allegiance to ego and short sightedness, as the Foreign Relations Committee and Republican opponents of the nuclear deal are showing here. They think that by drafting a bill that makes the president of the US look weak on the world stage they somehow appear strong? Wow. Exceptional reasoning.

Considering this is a multinational negotiation with Iran and none of the other countries are facing such internal legislative bulling, how do you think that plays? Perhaps the EU, Russia, China and England can simply lift the sanctions they imposed, and by doing so make the American decision irrelevant, or opt to leave the US out of the negotiations all together. Bravo Republicans. You really know how to win the day and show the world how exceptional we are.
After a treasonous open letter to Iran, they now want credit for the peaceful resolution? Unreal.
Here's the explanation: ISIS isn't the existential threat that the warmongers in both parties want us to believe.

b fagan, I'm sorry to say Kurt can be a close reader when he's looking for something he can alter to make it sound just enough different from the original to give a false impression. You need to watch out for this.

The posse's passion for misleading people involves some rather clever manipulation of material to make it say something different from the original.

For example, I got one about accusing McIntyre of being a crank because I quoted a good source that said he is a resource for cranks (note the difference). There is some distance between a crank and active malice or big fossil advocacy (very profitable, that, indirectly or directly). I've had a bellyful of McI's fans and their very specific malice; it made me feel quite like St. Sebastian, all prickled with arrows, funny in an acid kind of way.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Sebastian_(Mantegna)

Please allow me. The Senate sees that this president  says he could "snap back" sanctions if the Iranians cheated when it's clear that by then the entire world will have dropped  their embargo and that he will be powerless to do anything about it. They see that he is so desperate to close Guantanamo that he releases fighters who go back to the battlefield to kill Americans (we killed one such with a drone this very day). They see that Mr. Putin has decided to give the Iranians missile technology knowing this president will do nothing to make him pay a price; and in sum the Senate does not trust this president to look out for the people's interests in the world. Hope that clears it up for you.
This heart warming story is so very helpful in adjusting one’s understanding  of our wonderful human experiences.  Thank You!
I want to thank the author Mr. Yardley for digging up this story and speleogeling it to the walls of our buried human history.
Worthy material for a fine novel . . .
Sad that involving the government seems to ruin everything.  You would think the government would be a bit more nimble in responding to these generous souls.
What a wonderful adventure for the Faggiano's. I wonder whether the son who moved to London ever visits any of the Roman ruins in Britain.
This is the best thing I've read all year.
Great sentiment.  I personally think the maker of those artifacts would be very pleased to know how much love and appreciation his work is receiving now.
Well thought out verse, thanks

When I dig beneath my lot
and find an ancient painted vase,
glistening in a secret vault,
I'll go back to my house and brood,
if it would do me any good,
to pursue ghosts that are long gone,
ancient treasures let them lie,
buried in their caverns deep,
they're not there to satisfy,
obsessions I cannot put to sleep,
yet what's the harm in knowing more,
about the folks who went before,
uncovering the lives of the vanished kind
is a natural intoxicant,
arguing thus me versus me,
the next day, I am sure, I would return
pick ax in hand--
a somnambulist--
to do the bidding of the past,
even without a shred of proof
that the sub terrain is rich or vast.
Viv' Il Faggiani!

volcanic expulsions - tectonic plate movement - wind shifting soil and sand over 8,000 years - now with 20th it's 20,000 years, just as the earth shifted into today's nations and islands = add time and voila!

I can’t help you much with the geology, besides noting that there is a good deal of volcanic activity not far away. But, as in Rome and other places where you have layers of civilization built one on top of the other, much of the foundation of each subsequent layer is composed of the detritus of the previous one. Burnt and wrecked buildings become rubble, and rubble, continually crushed and mixed with organic matter, becomes the ground for a new foundation. I have heard that something like this, happening at an accelerated rate, was observed in the ruins of heavily bombed cities after WW II. New buildings went up on what had suddenly become a higher ground level than the one remembered only a few years before. No doubt Lecce, like Rome and Jerusalem, is “a city builded on her own heap.” In any case, from my one brief visit there, I can tell you it is a marvellous place, even more for her baroque architecture than for her antiquities. Go there if you can.

In Istanbul it's fascinating how many buildings have basements where you can see ancient walls and foundations that have been unearthed in the construction of the new buildings.  The basement breakfast room of our hotel had old stone foundations down the center of it.  An added treat when we had a late night snack at a nearby restaurant was descending to the excavations taking place below the building and seeing the ancient construction there.

I'm not familiar with the area. Can someone please explain to me how these civilizations were built on top of each other. Maybe more accurately, where did the soil come from to bury the previous civilizations?
Us.
Why think that people always have ulterior motives?
A perfect example of why I love Italy.
New York only seems millennial, just as London and Paris only seem ancient until compared to Rome.

It does make sense to make it harder to gain an exemption than get the vaccinations. But how to do that?

When I first started teaching, at a very small public school, it was my job to ensure that my incoming kindergarten students were up to date on vaccinations. Our state had a very lenient policy for personal exemptions, but back then (early 80's) it was more about parents forgetting or just not being organized enough. With a little nudge most parents (moms) would get their kids the shots. But as the years went by, the school nurses became more interested in filling out the state forms than getting kids shots. I was told to just have the parents fill out the personal exemption form so we would be in compliance. So in fact, maybe there were governmental actors who were shooting the states in the foot.
at first I read "I have to go now..."  power of suggestion.

It's like Aladdin's cave. Fascinating.

Nothing like that under the house where I grew up, I'm sure. But many years later I was deeply thrilled to discover online that there's a long-buried river running underground not far from my childhood home.
There were people around for thousands of years before New York was built.  They just didn't have as much "stuff".
